reviewText:
I very VERY rarely post anything in game reviews.

I thought I would for a change.

Great fun.  Have over 300 hours of play time in this game.  Worked really hard to get good weapons and gear which is hard to do with the RNG in this game.
PVE was fun and the Hard modes when leveling up were hard and again very fun.
Once 30 I loved the Challenge modes and the DZ.

The game environment is amazing and the attention to the small details is great.  The first couple of weeks I was still astounded by the little details I hadn't noticed and kept seeing.

However.... DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

I am DZ rank 92.  I have 23594 kills in the game, 2756 items extracted, 269 Rogue agent kills.  The DZ however is broken.... really really badly.  The DZ is the PVP enabled area.  It is full of intensity, are you going to get those items out via extraction or will someone come and try to kill/engage you to take your loot from you.

I literally love the DZ, but it is broken.  There is no balance. After the 1.1 incursion DLC was released it literally doesn't matter how much health you have as the DPS is SOOOOO large now it is basically first to shoot wins.

On top of that there is a prolific cheater problem.  You CANNOT go rogue anymore as you will die to a cheater that is shooting through walls or teleporting behind you or flying or in a building.  You literally die almost instantly to cheaters.

It is such a shame, this game has all the potential to be amazing.  The DZ is awesome and the intensity they have created with it is so much fun but they are not addressing the biggest issues this game face which are the cheaters and the game balance in the PVP area.

One day they might fix it and get rid of the cheaters but the population for this game is already seeping away. http://steamcharts.com/app/365590 the game is on a steady decline in users.

The forums are awash with people complaining about cheaters.

Just save your money.  This game is not worth the heartbreak you will have.

reviewText: This game can only be optimally enjoyed by having friends that regularly log in to stomp around the Dark Zone with. I spent 60-ish hours on the story, thats with taking proper breaks between story missions and clearing out entire zones of all collectables before moving on. Most people complete the game in 8 hours. But the sell here was the MMO style of endless game, frequent content pushes, and plenty to do at the end of the game to keep you busy in between updates. Simply put, there is no end game. There are no 'raids'. There is no real content that you get to enjoy once reaching level cap. Their first Incursion/Operation content push literally puts you in a single large room with the main objective of destroying an enemy that doesn't move. The single tactic" available to complete said incursion requires you to eliminate 15 waves of super soldiers with ultra-bazooka-sniping-shotguns from hell that you truly have no actual way to defend yourself against other than hopefully killing them before they overrun you. That being said a vast majority of the player base has taken to using an endless variety of bugs and exploits to undermine the overall mechanics of the game. Hacking also has its expected place in the dark zone. In fact

reviewText:
My dear Division, it's time we go our separate ways... I tried to make it work, you know I did. I dedicated a lot of time just for you. Time that maybe I should've dedicated to my family, friends, work and studies. What we had wasn't casual.

I defended you against the initial negative reception. I accepted your graphical downgrade. I chose to ignore how absolutely ♥♥♥♥ed up your netcode is. I turned a blind eye on how almost all stats are calculated and stored on the client, and server just accepts it without any checking. I fell on deaf ears when realized you have no anti-cheat whatsoever. I chose to ignore the global networking architecture ♥♥♥♥up. I looked past your very limited character creation. I accepted that you could be boring at times. Even after i've done everything there is to do in the game, i kept on visiting you daily for several hours. I tried to convince myself, that the PvP would be the end-game, but yet again you disappoint me. The complete lack of end-game and limited content adds up to the recurring feeling there is nothing much to do in the game.

My friends kept asking me how could I go on with this. What they couldn't understand is that, although it was always hard to make things work between us, when they worked, it was something very special. I'm not rich, but still I bought new dresses for my characters. I bought the Gold Edition with Season Pass, even though i had no idea what would come with it. I trusted in you. I believed you.

The current state of the game is abysmal. Dozens of glitches ruined the player base progression. Clipping through walls, cheesy farming exploits all over, bugged weapon and equipment talents exploiting, Item duping, infinite money and infinite crafting materials. Not to mention the cheater infested Dark Zone, with free and paid hacks available on demand. Even a simple memory editor is enough for cheaters to give themselves infinite ammo, no reload, rapidfire, no recoil, speed hack and teleport. There is no light at the end of this tunnel, baby. It is a glitch-exploiting hack-infested ♥♥♥♥fest, it is a disaster. There is no in-game report feature, the only way is to record and manually report through the terrible support, only to have an answer many days later with a automated message, and later discover that the blatant cheater i reported still roaming the Dark Zone. How can a company that spent so much money on marketing, not hire a outsourced anti-cheat service such as FairFight and PunkBuster, at least to brake the cheating a little bit?

The time has come for me to change my review. I can't really recommend The Division for anyone in its current state. For my friends on Steam that see playing this game a lot in the past weeks, and might get interested in the game, i must warn you, the game is not worth your money or your time. Stay away from this game.

I could keep dreaming of the day when the wrongs will get fixed, when the flaws will get polished. But we both know that this will never happen. I held on for as long as I could, darling. But it's over. I hold no regrets, at least we tried, and we had our fun times. I sincerely hope one day we can work out our issues and come to terms. Deep down, i'll always remember you. But for now, it is time to move on.

If you want to try the game youll like it at first, but get max lvl, and then... what?

No thumbs up.

reviewText:
A game where you try to level up as fast as you can and occasionally pay attention to the story and the setting, which are the only good things this game has offered, and then realize you've really got better things to do than to shoot everybody on sight. If you just want a 30-hour game for your entertainment, go for it, but I simply don't want to pay such a high price for this game if I were given a second chance.

What you can do in this game:
Enjoy the nice environment
Enjoy the setting
Enjoy the interesting but somewhat dull plot
Run around Manhattan from one side to another
Exercise virtually with friends
Shoot everyone marked by a red arrow on sight
Empty an entire magazine just to kill one mid-level enemy with two health bars
Collect stuff
Sell stuff that you've collected
Start to get bored after 40 hours

reviewText:
I'm just going to post my reddit post because tis the most accurate info I can give anyone looking into this game.

Can a dev please explain to me why you thought it a good idea to give some random player in a group, leader with the power to unanimously kick whoever they want? I mean, a guy doesn't like your name? Kicked. Doesn't like the color shirt you're wearing? Kicked.

So I'm trying to load into a random group on clear sky, ok used to loading screens that's fine. Get into the group everyone is having the bug where you run into the mission area and get transported to the beginning. Ok we all leave group. Another loading screen. Alright I'm going to be patient because I want to try the new content and give this a chance. my gear score is 197, I get it not super high, but it is doable, I know this because I went 20 minutes through the mission yesterday before everyone got spam dced and we gave up. Ok so I join another random group, loading screen, load, I've been kicked already, another loading screen, back in safe zone. Alright well I'm sure that guy was just anal about things, lets give it another go. Loading screen, load, kicked already, back to safe zone. I can't do this game anymore, been patient but even outside of the bugs, which i don't mind giving developers time to fix, this god power you give to random people in groups is just a bad design decision.

This game is unique, exciting and fun, when it works. Right now it feels like archeage with some of these design decisions, rampant exploits (which are not resolved).

I want to love you and spend time and money on you Division. Help me help you.

reviewText: Absolutely awful. Let me give you a scenario. I'm playing a half hour long mission, I die 4 times because enemies kill you in 2 shots, bosses kill instantly. I finally kill the boss on the 5th attempt, not half a second later an invisible grenade of his blows up behind me, kills me, no way to get back up I am forced to give up. reviewText:
Editing review after 446 hrs and on 2nd game update.

This game is casual play at best. Yes a MMO is where you grind relentless hours for rare loot, crafting, earning in-game cash and building your character(s), but since they made the drops generous enough it spoils the chase of it and made it boring. The old missions you prolly would rarely play and just go for the top tier missions or go into the darkzone/pvp but the thrill, excitment and scared silly part of that is gone. Crafting is dead even though more supplies are needed, high end drops are raining in your inventory and flooded and the blueprints are lower tiered than the items dropped !

Will still play cuz I already bought this and anticipate to see what Tom Clancy's Wildland brings so I can jump ship.

reviewText: Now, at first I will admit, this game wasn't bad at all. In my opinion, this game had the potential to beat Destiny, but you start to realize after a while, the game gets repetitive and boring. Fight enemies, do this, grab this, fight these enemies and fight a boss at the end. It became a point to where me and my friends knew exactly what to do and didn't even need to worry about the final boss. Another thing that I would like to comment about is the dark zone. Good idea, bad execution. The dark zone is fun, don't get me wrong, but it is not fun alone. Sure you have the excitement of going rouge and killing enemies for really good loot, but I fall back to my last statement. Its repetitive. This game takes a lot of grinding to get some good gear, and sometimes that time is just wasted into doing what? Getting good gear, going back to use the gear in a mission and repeat the process? That's it. And of course like every game you're gonna find better loot and replace everything. It will repeat. To end this review, I do reccomend this for people who have time to grind and have friends to back them up. Sadly, I do not reccomend this to the community as a whole.

reviewText:
This game turned out to be the biggest let down I've had in a long time. Here are the reasons:
- Mindless farming for weapons and crafting components
- Weapons modification (more on that later)
- Good selection of cool skills that become absolutely useless in the hardest modes
- Character creation is a joke
- BORING
Ok so about this list. A lot of people have a problem with the lack of endgame content and while that is a problem for me, I would like to state that even while this game was in development long enough to have more, it is a newer game and we shouldn't expect miracles. That is the reason I did not list it in the reasons why this game lets me down.
The mindless farming of crafting components and gear is an extreme deterant for me. I hate MMOs for the most part. Why ? I'm glad you asked. Its because of the best gear" and the absolute need for it. This game would have been far better without it. This also brings me to the hardcore MMO gun modding system. I like a little more realism in my games and even if you don't
date: this modding system is stupid. Adding a scope should do nothing more than allow you to see your target better at range. Not add stats to a gun that it wouldn't add to a real gun. A scope doesn't add range IRL so why should it here. Clips add more ammo
recommended: why would that increase rate of fire ? This also makes some guns even more powerful than some of their counterparts. LVOA-C can get over 1000 rpm. So can the Mp5. Why would you use anything else in PvP where crit and rpm are the gods of combat. Crit is a stupid mechanic in this game because again
hoursPlayed: it makes SMGs far better at PvP than any other weapon. The rest I'm sure you can figure out if you decide to play this game. For me to play this game again
voteText:
The following would have to happen:
1. Remove the modding system stats. Making the guns more realistic.
2. Remove the game breaking crit damage system that ruins the game for people that don't want to use SMGs for PvP.
3. Make cloth purchasable and remove them from the drop system.
I guess in short this game needs to be far less MMO and far more realistic. It should not take 20-60 rounds of ammo to kill something. Player or not. There are far FAR more problems with this game but I'm not even going to go into that. Buyer beware. This game is exceptionally mediocre and there is NO replay value."

reviewText: In the beginning the game was fun to play with friends, but now if you have not played in a month or two it is very boring and is hard to get back into the game. The pve in the game is good, but after you get done with all of the pve objectives the game begins to get very bland and boring in pve. After beating everything outside of the dark zone you can only replay mission on different difficulties or do incursions. The pvp in the game is complete ♥♥♥♥ if you have not played in a long time. An example of this is I'm level 45 dz and a gear rank of 183 and I am constantly running into and being killed by 70 dz - 99 dz with 200+ gear score. If they add more things to do outside of the dark zone and balance the pvp a bit more the game will be a bit better. Over all they need to balance the game more, add in more content and fix the bugs in the game.

reviewText:
Yes, 400 hours into the game and I don't recommend it. Let's just say I'm not placing my interests in other games currently so I just use TCTD to kill time.

Reasons: (tl;dr below)

1. Glitch/exploit heaven
The infamous 'mobile cover' exploit is already causing enough troubles to create a severe imbalance in terms of players' gear. If you exploit/glitch a few mission runs, you're already streets ahead in terms of gear, compared to those who play this game legit (assuming that you two have the same amount of hours devoted into the game).

Plus, this game doesn't really have designated PvP gear separated from PvE gear. So whoever gets the better gear dominates the DZ, and the imbalance at the moment is so obvious that it disrupts PvP enjoyment.

2. Blatant hacking
There are quite a number of hackers in this game, and they don't try to hide it as well. It won't affect PvE, but you pretty much have to enter the DZ to farm at some point, so you can't hide from PvP forever anyway.

Some aimhack, some adjust stats so that they're invincible, some fly in the sky, some teleport when they're near death, and some shoot through buildings too. Now, I'm not saying that you'll bump into one every time you enter the DZ, but it's a frequent occurrence.

3. Gameplay imbalance
The new gear sets render armour mitigation and HP count almost obsolete. Stacking health to tank PvP damage is certainly not the best way to go. With the new gear set bonuses, you can easily tear through a player running a tank build. It just doesn't feel balanced at all, compared to the beta releases.

4. Lack of free-roaming encounters
After you've reached PvE level 30, the PvE map is literally empty. There are some low-leveled minions at designated spawn areas, but that's it. They aren't even a threat to you if you're geared properly. They just tickle your HP. A huge waste of the map potential I must say.

5. Un-rewarding loot system
The loot drops are way too trash for end-game players to have an incentive to continue grinding. It'll take ages before you get lucky with a rare item with good stat/talent rolls. If they don't calibrate the drop rates and system anytime soon, I'd be quitting the game as well!

tl;dr
Don't buy this game because
- Hackers are everywhere in PvP, it's a joke right now
- No effective counter-measures to deter glitchers/exploiters yet, rendering gear imbalance amongst players
- PvE has little to no content after you reach PvE lvl 30
- PvE loot drop system does not reward you with useful items often enough (words from a 400 hour player so it does carry some weight)
- PvP is imbalanced, it doesn't feel tactical at all unless they adjust the ridiculous damage output offered by the new gear set items

reviewText:
Game had (past tense) potential but right now I have to write this review and completely not recommend buying this game unless they sell it for 80% off.

Pros
- The campaign is the only thing that is great about this geam.  I can see Ubisoft making DLC and just focus on the story line

Cons
- Everything not related to the campaign
- Multiplayer
#1  Flodded with exploiters
#2  No concept of pvp or pve server.  This way, people can farm for their gears in the darkzone without getting killed while calling for extraction.  Anybody who wants to do pvp can join the pvp server. At least everyone knows what they are getting into
#3 Banning of exploiters.  They ban exploiters but WILL NOT TELL you what you did wrong except that you should read the code of conduct.  So how does someone know that the reason you got ban is because you mapped your skill buttons to a logitech mouse that has at least 12 programmable buttons.  Does the code of conduct tell you not to use macro button enable mices?

Really, this is a shame. Great game in the beginning and it just declines all the way down


Conclusion:  You are buying this game for the storyline period.  Go watch 3-4 movies instead of buying this game

reviewText:
It was the backstory that prompted me to pre-order 'the Division' and was looking forward to something different - dirty, gruesome and truly apocolyptic.

Unfortunately, the leveling, the statistics, the grinding and cute little uniforms and colors just kinda did it in for me.

It started out well and worked itself into the backstory.  Unfortunately they ran out fast and what was left was grinding  and leveling.

The two most recent DLCs was kinda pathetic, a big room, with a big gun you have to defeat at one end and an endless number of adversaries to overcome.

It did have a lot of promise but...

Just like many games and companies with great ideas, they lack the vision to make it epic.

reviewText: I am over 200 hours in game and I QUIT.  I had fun until I reached Level 30.  I have tried and tried to survive the Dark Zone only to get killed over and over again.  I know no other players so when I team up with random players (something you need to do to build up your stats) I get turned on and killed by them, they depart my team because I am not a very high level, or some very powerful guy just comes up and kills me.  The designers made the dark zone unfair on purpose.  He who has the biggest stats (guns, etc) wins.  The little guy like me trying to build up is toast.  I have watched a lot of Youtube and lots of guys think it is really cool to pretend to team up with you and then kill you.  I have even been killed by one shot when behind a wall (somehow the guy shot through the wall and killed me with one shot).  When you go to extract your loot, one of the guys that was helping you comes up to you at the last second when you are loading your gear on the rope (and can't defend yourself), kills you and takes your stuff.  The game is no longer fun, I QUIT.

reviewText:
I should have taken advantage of all the exploits and glitches like so many other people who are so far ahead of us currently.

I logged in to check out the new patch, did the dark zone daily things first, went well. Saw no other agents and picked up a few golds from random mob packs with bosses.

Queue for Falcon Lost and I get in a group but I seem to be stuck at the entrance while my group seems somewhere inside these gates in front of me.  I leave group, try again, except there's another guy stuck outside with me. Ask in chat channel, no reply. Shouldn't have to exit a game to search forums to figure out why a game isn't working. Give up.

Queue for Daily Challenge, Power Plant, I'm 183, 140k dps, 80k health, 14k tech, not garbage.  We get about 20 minutes in, leader kicks someone. Then kicks me.

Queue for Daily Challenge, We get about 2 minutes in and 2 of my guys are balls deep inside the walls and dead. 2 of us try to clear to them but shotgun wave. 2 people leave group.

Queue for Daily Challenge, leader's afk at safe house. This is boring already.

4/10 - Fun to shoot things though.

Would not recommend to enemy.

reviewText:
8/ 10 PvE --- 4/10 PvP(prehackzone, unplayable thereafter)
At times repetitive but challenging and fun when grouped along with the crafting/upgrading system. Played this nonstop the first few weeks after lauch.

I really wont bother to comment on the PvP and endgame too much, as you can read everything else posted here. If you like to grind nonstop mindlessly, you may not mind the endgame, but the dropoff in quality was fairly pronounced imo. I only made it to around level 30 in the DZ before I hung it up. There just isnt any payoff and the random battles you'll have aren't very engaging or balance, both real player and npc.
Few times I hopped on since updates, I was either falling through maps, or being kicked from groups for too low of GS (which didnt exist when I started) or kicked for not realizing they were using some exploit and aggro'ing the ai. Gave that up quick.

Great game, but not a long term one for those who hate the grinding. If you can set that aside I still think its worth playing the story at least once, ONLY with the half off sales from time to time.

In short, I'm glad to have played it and feel like a herb for buying the gold package(lesson learned), but truly wouldn't recommend it if you're really expecting longevity of play. Half off for the story? Not the worst deal.

reviewText:
Tom Clancy’s The Division™ - review 1.1
Game encourage cheating
A completely bs awful loot drop rate with some of the worst loot I have ever seen  I mean seriously... 30 minutes to a possible hour for a set piece you don't even want? OR something you did want and the stats are complete junk? Hell I have seen purples with better stats The worst is the horde mode where the devlopers themselves COULD NOT EVEN COMPLETE challenge mode and then it's laid upon us the consumer, and we are expected to do what a devloper couldn't when they already have the best stuff? I am just stunned they even thought this was a good idea. Grenade dodging simulator 2016? I like the idea of jumping around for half an hour without firing a single shot.

Crafting after 1.1The 1.1 incurisons update is by far one of the worst changes i have seen in this game. Might make me stop playing altogether. I do not understand the logic behind this.

*Crafting before 1.1
5 green to make 1 blue
25 green to make 1 HE
200 green to make LVL31 item
5 blue to make 1 HE
40 blue to make 1 LVL 31 item
8 HE to make 1 LVL31 item

*Crafting after 1.1
10 green to make 1 blue - 2x more - 200% nerf
150 green to make 1 HE - 6x more - 600% nerf
1,500 green to make 1 LVL 31 item - 7.5x more - 750% nerf
15 blue to make 1 HE - 3x more - 300% nerf
150 blue to make 1 LVL 31 item - 3.75x more - 375% nerf
10 HE to make 1 LVL 31 item - 25% more - 25% nerf

The Phoenix CreditsPhoenix Credits drop have been in(de)creased on lvl 31 and 32 named enemies:
Level 30: 1-3 Phoenix Credits
Level 31: 2-4 Phoenix Credits
Level 32: 3-5 Phoenix Credits

Phoenix credit limit at 1000 -.-

The upcoming DLCs
Tom Clancy's The Division Episode 1 The Perfect Lie
Tom Clancy's The Division Episode 2 Incursion of Nerfs
Tom Clancy's The Division Episode 3 Thanks for Your Money, We are shutting it Down.

It's unbelievable how they made such a development decision. That means that if you choose any type of accessory for your characte you have to stick with them forever. You can't take them off. Ugly face-paint included. It's like they didn't even bother to care about this at all...

reviewText:
I will try to make it short.

Lets start with the positive things.
The setting of the game is great. The graphics are 2016 standard. However, The textures, especially of the environment (buildings, cars, etc) are really low res. (I have a GTX980Ti running everything on ultra)

The first 10-20 hours or so the game was really thrilling.
After doing all the main missions and side mission (basically 4 different types repeating) and collecting all collectibles, the game gets boring really fast.

After you reach lvl30 there is not really anything to do.
You can grind DZ ranks (I gave up at around rank 60) which takes forever and is boring as hell because basically you just do the same farming route over and over again.
There is so much running involved. The enemy density should be much higher.
Imagine you have to walk 2-5 minutes to get to a pack of enemies. Gunfight for maybe 30 seconds. Done. Run another 5 minutes. Repeat. That is your basic dark zone gameplay.

Same (4 different) NPC types. Same mission types.

The first incursion also lacks really good ideas.
Basically, it is a big closed hall where you are forced to move out of cover all the time and swarmed by enemies that spawn all over the place (of course behind you) in 15 waves. Great idea.

Then there are the cheaters!
It seems that nobody really cares, it seems everybody is doing it. The game has no anti-cheat mechanism.

I almost forgot the bugs. The game is full of bugs, glitches and exploits. It is unbelievable.
Just as an example: You enter matchmaking, teleport to the instance and the doors are closed (meaning you cant start the mission). I could not find out whether there is any way to fix this except for re-trying to enter for 10 times.
Another one: You just fall through the floor of the game world, then you are teleported to the safe house, bleed out and die.
Another one: You shoot and your SMG gets stuck" at 1 or 2 rounds left in the magazine. You cannot shoot nor reload. Great in PvP.
You have to change your weapon and switch back. Then for some reason your magazine is half full.

The game is fun for a while if you consider it as a single player game
date: but as MMO it completely failed in my view."
hoursPlayed: false

reviewText: To put it short, a whole lot of nothing in a very VERY pretty package.\n\nThing is that when you first start this you get the feel that everything is possible and the world is yours to explore! After 15 levels you realize how limited the game really is and how limited the options are what's around the corner. Well like every good gamer I chose to cap my character becouse then the game really starts, right? Something starts alright, the PVP that is the most unwelcome I've yet seen. You get the extraction zone camping and griefing (and in the worst case scenario if you actually happen to have any loot, it get's ninjaed). Problem is, there is really not a lot to do in the PVE area so you are proned to go to the PVP are (DarkZone), get griefed, redo, griefed (even corpse gank)... I've heard good things when you are grouped up but don't have experience of that. Don't really know many that play this and have learned way back when that PUG is not an option. The game offers pick up group action if one wishes to go that route but we all know from our mmorpg days how those options are so let me know if you give it a try. Might I add that the economy of the game has already collapsed (yes peeps farm way too much) AND partly the game seems even unfinished (for example, changing not so good material into better you have to do manually one by one).  Positive note, the game looks VERY sharp and pretty. If you have a high end machine and extra 60 bucks that you really really don't find any other place to spend, go for it, it'll knock you on your butt the first time you get at it. After 3 hours don't expect anything new, though.

reviewText:
I was so excited for this game when I first found out about it. The graphics are great IMO if you have a computer powerful enough to play at max settings. The story is pretty fun honestly... but once you finish it (you can probably finish it in 3-4 days if you have a life outside of computer games), its pure repetition.

If you don't have time to play this game everyday for a couple of hours (I don't) this game is simply not worth it. You have to keep playing the same bosses over and over to get decent gear. The best weapons are found in the DZ, but whats the point in even trying to go to the DZ when you constantly encounter people with way better weapons than yours? You'll get shot down by a--holes with gear scores higher than 200 who purposely run around the DZ killing everyone with lower gear scores since it takes them 5 bullets max to do so, however, its takes you at least 2 full clips (if not more) to down them ONLY if you're lucky enough that they forget to use a health pack. I'm talking about legit players too, don't get me started on hackers who use RPM, no clip, no spread and teleporting hacks to steal your gear. Ubisoft and Massive's claim that they are doing something about hackers but in reality I don't even think they can because to my eyes its only getting wrose everyday. On top that you are rewarded so few DZ funds and Phoenix Credits that even if there were no hackers and there were better ways to separate people with higher ranks from lower ranked players, it still wouldn't be worth the amount of time it takes to grind through this game to get the best weapons. There are a lot of other problems that I just don't care to list right now but I'm sure there are plenty of other reviews on here that address them.

With all that being considered, I can ALMOST see why people would want to hack to play this game. However, IMO, if you have to hack just to feel like you have a fair chance, then the game simply is not worth playing anymore.

At the end of the day I guess I can't blame anyone but myself for pre-ordering this game though. I fell for Ubisoft's and Massive's gimmicks, so all I can do is congratulate them for fooling so many people like myself yet again. Do yourself a favor and skip this game.

Also, stop pre-ordering video games in general, let dumba--es like myself who can't learn their lesson tell you what to expect after a few weeks so you can make the right decision.

reviewText:
I waited for this game since E3 2013, and I preordered the game the moment it came onto steam, played the closed and opened beta, played everyday since luanch, have over 300hrs on the game in less than 2 months, plus over 50 hours for both betas together.

After playing so much, having so much expectation for this game, having some enjoyable moments in the world of The Division, I dont find the game fun anymore.

I am not going to talk about the gameplay or whatever that everyone has been criticising about the game. I am cool with everything the game has to offer.

However, if ubisoft does not clean up the servers, ban all hackers, and prevent any players from hacking, the game will never ever be fun again. I had enough of a group of hackers terrorizing in each DZ server.

I love this game and it was going to be my GOTY, but seriously, ubisoft's lack of commitment and action in punishing hackers and exploiters in fustrating and shaming to the whole gaming community and industry.

6/10 Light Zone, 1/10 Dark Zone

Comng from a guy that has been on The DIvision since closed beta, the game is not worth in its current state and administration.

reviewText:
If you want a expensive but pretty 3rd person action shooter that will last you through a weeked, pick this one up. It is actually quite fun for a few days, though be warned, it's a different Tom Clancy game. Forget realism and logic, think Fantasy cRPG with shooter mechanics.

And no, not RPG as in roleplaying, just RPG as in levels and stats and things like that. You're actually a mute without any saying or decisions to make what so ever. The leveling curve is quite steep (but fast) so be prepared for bullet sponge enemies (sometimes taking up to a mag per foe with at least half of the hits to the head) and wierd unrealistic stats on your gear. Diablo style! (My protective kneepads actually give me 120 bucks everytime I kill with a headshot. True story. That's Tom Clancy nowadays kids).

The open world is quite linear since you'll have to level to venture further, and once you clear encounters and open world missions the will never spawn back. The only thing you can repeat are the handful static instanced storymissions that will play out the same every time you play them. No randomization to be seen in gameplay. The same enemy waves spawn at the same place every single time.

When you've played through the story there's very little reason to stay. There's a open pvp area to grind, and as mentioned, you can repeat the story missions. The sole reason to keep playing is to find better loot, but the economic and RNG mechanics are quite uninspiring making this somewhat frustrating and boring rather quickly. If you want a long lasting game, look somwhere else.

The game also suffers from bugs (some of the reported in beta, but still around), gamebreaking exploitable glitches and on the PC also active cheaters. Ubisoft support does very little to help players in need and patches from Massive are minimalistic and far between, mostly breaking more than they fix.


TL:DR
Fun arcadish game for a while, but with short a lifespan due to limited content and glitches.

reviewText:
Cheating galore. Ubisoft/Massive suck too much a** to fix anything. The cheating ranges from all different kinds of PvE exploits to actual 3rd party programs allowing cheats in the DZ(PvP). From forcing the respawn of a mob that isn't supposed to respawn(PvE) to teleporting(Mostly PvP) and being instantly killed by a guy one block over, through a building(PvP), this game has seen it all. Many of the cheats are still running rampant. They've fixed a few but those fixes have just lead to the discovery of other exploits/cheats.

They speak of swinging the ban hammer but I consistently run in to cheaters in the DZ who express very little worry about being recorded while in the act of cheating. Uplay was also set up so your Uplay name is your ingame name. You can change your Uplay name as often as you want. They can cheat around the DZ then just change their Uplay name and move on. I'm also thinking(not sure) there's a 3rd party program out there that allows them to mask their real Uplay name/account. The absolute lack of worry from ALL of them that I've come across is very unsettling. I'm convinced their lack of worry is justified as Ubisoft/Massive has just completely failed up to this point and will probably continue well into the future of this game.

I know it's not a real, complete review of the actual game but this was all I could focus on as the cheating is EVERYWHERE.

I posted a video in my profile of my most recent encounter with a cheater. It's at least worth a chuckle if you want to check it out.

EDIT: Jumped into a challenge mode Falcon Lost(endgame, if you can call it that) with some buddies(all of us have done it multiple times) and we just quit because our signature skill effects wouldn't activate when we used the skill. Bugs, bugs, and more bugs. This game is an incomplete POS. I'm usually ok with a game not being perfect for a bit after release as long as the dev team is on top of it. This team isn't even trying. Buyer beware.

reviewText: At first glance this game is awesome. Then the glitches set in. After the glitches its the story that sort of becomes background noise to a more interesting pvp mode/dark zone. After the pvp mode/dark zone loses its appeal its the zero end game content. After the end game content....you get the picture.  The two note worthy mentions about this game are the combat and loot system. The combat system is semi realistic and can leave you with a sense of accomplishment after taking down a hard boss or troubelsome group of badies. There is ALOT of loot in this game. Different weapon and armor stats help you customize your characters abilities and help transform what at first is alot of walking with boring encounters into a virtual warpath of chaos and destruction. The Co-Op is an honorable mention because when it works it really works. However if you are grouping with people you dont know and cannot communicate properly they can royally screw a mission or encounter up. This is the case in most games but I thought I would mention it for the simple fact that I have had enjoyable succesfull moments of Co-Op. Its no praise the sun feeling but you get it. I wanted this game to be amazeballs. I feel a little let down after all the hype and awesome gameplay reveals. I wont say that this game is unplayable but I cannot recommend it. If you are going to get the game wait for a sale or for the game to drop in price. Its not currently worth 60 bucks. Good day.

reviewText:
An unoriginal and unpolished cover based shooter, and don't forget that it's a console port. Where should I start? How about with something I can actually enjoy about this game? There is a great multiplayer aspect to this game called the Dark Zone, a free for all PVP area where the NPCs are beasts and the players are jerks. It's a kill all, loot all, bullet-fest and I absolutely love it when I get my 2 buddies with me and we go hit rogues.

That's the only nice thing I can say about this crap heap. Here comes a page worth of notes I've taken on how this game is absolutely god awful. And by the way? I didn't buy this game. My friend got it for me, and as much as I love the guy, I really wish he hadn't.

So I said the multiplayer is good. That's IF your friends all start and play the game with you, together, all the time, because this game religiously punishes anyone attempting to group out of their level range. And I don't mean something like 10 levels, no, the best range you can hope to be functional together at is about 2-3. If you encounter an NPC who is 4 levels over you? Your ♥♥♥ is grass. And guess what every single enemy, from the open world to your instances, is going to be? The level of the highest level person in the group. So forget about joining your high level friend. It won't happen. It can't happen, unless you're some kind of masochist.

And then there's the content you'll be going through. Lackluster is just the tip of the iceberg here. You've only got the most basic of go for" mission types. It's either go here and press a button

reviewText: I have no idea what the developers of this game were thinking. This game is unfinished. Literally half a game. The end game content is just replaying the same garbage over and over again. All the skill is put into gear drops. You only win via being out geared than your opponent. Ain't no body got time for that! 75% of the skills are dumb and pointless. Same for perks. This game is a WORSE version than Mass Effect 3 multiplayer! yep! that's right! an added mode is better than a full game. The gameplay is nearly identicle. Cover based shooting, two abilities. Except there are 3 enemy factions. They all share the same 10 enemy types. So really only 10 enemy types in the game. This game is extremely boring. Mass effect was able to get away with such a thing because it had amazing enemy, story, environment, and abilities. The only thing this game did right was the graphics. I'm not someone that can be tricked by pretty things.\n\nDO NOT BUY, wait for several updates. This game needs help.

reviewText:
I waited for this game since E3 2013, and I preordered the game the moment it came onto steam, played the closed and opened beta, played everyday since luanch, have over 300hrs on the game in less than 2 months, plus over 50 hours for both betas together.

After playing so much, having so much expectation for this game, having some enjoyable moments in the world of The Division, I dont find the game fun anymore.

I am not going to talk about the gameplay or whatever that everyone has been criticising about the game. I am cool with everything the game has to offer.

However, if ubisoft does not clean up the servers, ban all hackers, and prevent any players from hacking, the game will never ever be fun again. I had enough of a group of hackers terrorizing in each DZ server.

I love this game and it was going to be my GOTY, but seriously, ubisoft's lack of commitment and action in punishing hackers and exploiters in fustrating and shaming to the whole gaming community and industry.

6/10 Light Zone, 1/10 Dark Zone

Comng from a guy that has been on The DIvision since closed beta, the game is not worth in its current state and administration.

reviewText: So im going to start with this the gameplay is different when first loading up the game. the graphics are insanely good but without friends what is this game? Well it's an infinite loop if glitches and hacking your way through the game there are no mechanics to the incursions its just the same boring point shoot heal revive boost and die, the damage tables are waaayyyy off, meaning your gear does not represent your true damage armor health or electronics, your stash capicity is smaller than your backpack, there are hackers in the DZ, crafting is not worth the grind, and they are STILL HAVING CONNECTION ISSUES. Want to try your luck in the DZ? well better have cheat engine loaded up cause everyone is using it.  glitches will forever remain in the game (i believe the game is client side so there will always be glitches) there are hackers in the DZ, the chat is always being spammed by people selling incursion runs while others are sending malware through the game. free roaming is the only way to get away from the hackers but nothing to really enjoy in the free roam area echos and other collectables are glitched so you cant recieve the end game items because of it and did i mention there are hackers in the DZ? there are no competitive aspects of the DZ unless you are competitively hacking.In the end i believe the only players that will be on this game are the hackers.

reviewText:
Was fun at start, and then the hackers became more than the normal gamers. And we lost the war, we lost New York. None of my friends log into the game now, because of the massive (intentional use of this word lol) problems. The game seems to get more and more broker after each patch/fix, so at this state I cannot recommend it. Which is a shame, The division has potential, but I doubt I will log again in it.

Graphics are nice,
Missions are somewhat dull
Crafting (was big part of the game) extreme farmy
Dark Zones (PVP) is a hacker zone
No open world PVE endgame,
Incursion used to be raid based themed DLC - added 1 instance mission for 4 players
Too much bugs/exploits that are not fixed

Sorry Division guys, gave you a month and 200 hours playtime, things are not getting better, kinda regret I bought the Gold edition.

reviewText: I hate to do this but I feel I need to warn off people who are considering buying this game. As someone with a decent amount of time on record playing and someone who was initially happy playing this game, take it from me, this game is broken in its current form. At the time of writing this, there are numerous glitches and exploits that allow players to have infinite ammo, ridiculous amounts of DPS, and constantly replenishing health. On top of that, there seems to be a decent amount of hackers roaming the Dark Zone as well. I saw all of the hate the steam community has for Ubisoft before this game came out but didn't really believe it. Well now that I've see that every time they intervene, and it gets worse, how bad they really are. And, there are problems that have been around since the game came out that havn't been fixed or took so long to fix that they can't undo the damage. So, unless Ubisoft gets their ♥♥♥♥ together, the pvp is broken and therefore the game. So, if you wanna bet on Ubisoft, buy this game and lose that bet.

reviewText:
An unoriginal and unpolished cover based shooter, and don't forget that it's a console port. Where should I start? How about with something I can actually enjoy about this game? There is a great multiplayer aspect to this game called the Dark Zone, a free for all PVP area where the NPCs are beasts and the players are jerks. It's a kill all, loot all, bullet-fest and I absolutely love it when I get my 2 buddies with me and we go hit rogues.

That's the only nice thing I can say about this crap heap. Here comes a page worth of notes I've taken on how this game is absolutely god awful. And by the way? I didn't buy this game. My friend got it for me, and as much as I love the guy, I really wish he hadn't.

So I said the multiplayer is good. That's IF your friends all start and play the game with you, together, all the time, because this game religiously punishes anyone attempting to group out of their level range. And I don't mean something like 10 levels, no, the best range you can hope to be functional together at is about 2-3. If you encounter an NPC who is 4 levels over you? Your ♥♥♥ is grass. And guess what every single enemy, from the open world to your instances, is going to be? The level of the highest level person in the group. So forget about joining your high level friend. It won't happen. It can't happen, unless you're some kind of masochist.

And then there's the content you'll be going through. Lackluster is just the tip of the iceberg here. You've only got the most basic of go for" mission types. It's either go here and press a button

reviewText:
This game was fun when it first released and while leveling I had a blast with it. However the game is riddled with bugs and it's so notorious easy to cheat that even people who utilize paid hacks complain that there are too many hackers. massive clearly has no idea how to manage an MMO like this. They release only a small amount of end game content coupled with the ability to completely grind your face off for gear means you can be done" with the end game rather quickly.

The gear is also set up terribly. It's the worst parts of Diablo and WoW gearing set up into one system where you may be looking for a specific piece of gear but there's no concrete way to obtain that gear and even if you do RNG plays a heavy roll in determining it's stats. You may reroll one stat per piece of gear but it gets insanely expensive to do so after only one roll.

There is a good base game here but Massive needs to fix both the way they handle end game and how buggy and easy to exploit the game itself is. As it stands I will not be buying any future DLC for this title."
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
how to make pancakes

Whisk 1 1/2 cups flour, 3 tablespoons sugar, 1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder, 1/2 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon baking soda in a medium bowl.

Whisk 1 cup plus 2 tablespoons milk, 4 tablespoons melted butter and 1 egg in a separate bowl; fold into the flour mixture until just combined (it's OK if there are some lumps).

Brush a large nonstick skillet or griddle with butter and heat over medium-low heat. Add ¼ cupfuls of batter and cook until bubbly on top and golden on the bottom, about 4 minutes. Flip and cook until golden on the bottom, about 2 more minutes. (Makes 6 to 8 pancakes.)

reviewText:
Pros with game:
1. Great story and playthrough in story mode until achieving rank 30. After that, its all downhill and I regret purchasing the game on PC.

Cons with game:
1. Constant falling through map, especially in Darkzone. Makes game unplayable in certain areas.

2. Darkzones PVP just doesnt work. Its not a true PVP, rather a PVP/PVE hybrid that doesnt funciton well as there are no clear sides. Most often, you find your self in a PVP situation after a neutral" player has unloaded a magazine in your back which downs you enabling them to steal your loot. No loot grind game has done this for obvious reasons. Only semi eazy to get loot games like DayZ and Rust. The high end loot games like Diablo 3 kept away from this for a good reason. You dont want to farm for several hours or days for that end game item only to have it stolen from you.

3. Hackers

reviewText:
I will try to make it short.

Lets start with the positive things.
The setting of the game is great. The graphics are 2016 standard. However, The textures, especially of the environment (buildings, cars, etc) are really low res. (I have a GTX980Ti running everything on ultra)

The first 10-20 hours or so the game was really thrilling.
After doing all the main missions and side mission (basically 4 different types repeating) and collecting all collectibles, the game gets boring really fast.

After you reach lvl30 there is not really anything to do.
You can grind DZ ranks (I gave up at around rank 60) which takes forever and is boring as hell because basically you just do the same farming route over and over again.
There is so much running involved. The enemy density should be much higher.
Imagine you have to walk 2-5 minutes to get to a pack of enemies. Gunfight for maybe 30 seconds. Done. Run another 5 minutes. Repeat. That is your basic dark zone gameplay.

Same (4 different) NPC types. Same mission types.

The first incursion also lacks really good ideas.
Basically, it is a big closed hall where you are forced to move out of cover all the time and swarmed by enemies that spawn all over the place (of course behind you) in 15 waves. Great idea.

Then there are the cheaters!
It seems that nobody really cares, it seems everybody is doing it. The game has no anti-cheat mechanism.

I almost forgot the bugs. The game is full of bugs, glitches and exploits. It is unbelievable.
Just as an example: You enter matchmaking, teleport to the instance and the doors are closed (meaning you cant start the mission). I could not find out whether there is any way to fix this except for re-trying to enter for 10 times.
Another one: You just fall through the floor of the game world, then you are teleported to the safe house, bleed out and die.
Another one: You shoot and your SMG gets stuck" at 1 or 2 rounds left in the magazine. You cannot shoot nor reload. Great in PvP.
You have to change your weapon and switch back. Then for some reason your magazine is half full.

The game is fun for a while if you consider it as a single player game
date: but as MMO it completely failed in my view."

reviewText: To put it short, a whole lot of nothing in a very VERY pretty package.\n\nThing is that when you first start this you get the feel that everything is possible and the world is yours to explore! After 15 levels you realize how limited the game really is and how limited the options are what's around the corner. Well like every good gamer I chose to cap my character becouse then the game really starts, right? Something starts alright, the PVP that is the most unwelcome I've yet seen. You get the extraction zone camping and griefing (and in the worst case scenario if you actually happen to have any loot, it get's ninjaed). Problem is, there is really not a lot to do in the PVE area so you are proned to go to the PVP are (DarkZone), get griefed, redo, griefed (even corpse gank)... I've heard good things when you are grouped up but don't have experience of that. Don't really know many that play this and have learned way back when that PUG is not an option. The game offers pick up group action if one wishes to go that route but we all know from our mmorpg days how those options are so let me know if you give it a try. Might I add that the economy of the game has already collapsed (yes peeps farm way too much) AND partly the game seems even unfinished (for example, changing not so good material into better you have to do manually one by one).  Positive note, the game looks VERY sharp and pretty. If you have a high end machine and extra 60 bucks that you really really don't find any other place to spend, go for it, it'll knock you on your butt the first time you get at it. After 3 hours don't expect anything new, though.

reviewText: Game was very fun for  the campaign and the quest to level 30 (max level at time of this review).  End game content was  just the usual carrot on a stick gear grind.  I had high hopes that this game was going to be for hardcore twitch shooter but it turned out to be a bullet spongy grind fest for gear.  I do not like gear grinds for the sake of gear grinds. Darkzone combat is mostly gank fests and a grind the best gear and then the best gear wins.  Players can take larges amount of bullet damage in pvp, multiple clips, which  takes away from the realism of the the awesome city massive built.  I just don't find it fun as a competitive shooter.  If I wanted to play a mmo for gear I'd hop on FFXIV.  If I want to play hardcore twitch shooter I'll play rainbow six siege.  The Division doesn't do either very well and ultimately falls kinda flat.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game, I really did. In its current state this game is unplayable, constant bugs like falling through the ground, getting stuck on walls and of course the constant glitches associated with the skill mobile cover, not to mention all the exploits like switching skills for 5-10 minutes to get infinite dps, an extreme abundance of hackers with things like 300% movement speed, fully automatic bolt action rifles and the dudes that can shoot you through walls from 200+ meters away. and the best part about the hackers is half the time you cant even report them because in Ubisofts infinite programming wisdom added characters that arent recognized by the game yet are possible to make a name with, so hackers run around with names like llIl.II.llIl.Il or llIllIIIlIlIl - There's no spam filter in the game so people just setup bots and leave them for days and most of these bots also have these unreportable, unignorable names. all on top of the ever amazing Delta Errors, I was playing with 3 friends the other day, got to wave 14/15 on Falcon Lost Challenge which is currently the hardest thing in the game for the best loot, took almost 45 minutes to get there and right as wave 14 ended we all recieved a Delta Error simultaneously and the instance restarted because it counted as a wipe. That is game breaking, that is unplayable. I really hope Ubisoft gets its ♥♥♥♥ together but right now it doesn't seem like it's going to happen within the next couple months, this game has more bugs and glitches than most Alphas I've played. Honestly probably gonna start hacking cuz Ubi clearly doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ if you do or dont.

reviewText:
There arn't enough words to describe how badly this game is put together. I've put roughly 300-400 hours on this game and I've tried to look for every positive. Unfortunately there arn't many. So let's get the positives out of the way first so i can get to the point of this review.
-Nice graphics
That's it and that is all it ever will be, just nice graphics. Being a level 30 PvE and a Dark Zone rank of 90 i found this game to be grindy. So then i tried the PvP aspect of it and nothing but hackers and exploiters. I've seen it all now guys, the flying to the teleporting right on top of you just to kill you and teleport away. The best part is, these guys can kill you (not down you) IN ONE SHOT and what's funny about this is that they only get a slap on the rist for hacking Massive's game and killing you, taking your xp and loot. Before getting this game, look up youtube videos on the division hacks. Now, just imagine these guys in every server taking your ♥♥♥♥ everytime they just simply look at you. They have a multistep process for reporting guys like these (all of this has to be done in order for them to get banned)
1. Record 3 instances of them hacking
2. Type /report *Hacker's Name* in chat (you won't get to see their name half of the time)
3. Post it to one of their forums (either reddit, facebook, or other means)
Now after you have completed all of this you may go continue back to the game and get ♥♥♥♥♥ slapped by the same hacker until the next game-update (its when they ban people).

So that was only the tiny segment of what hacking is currently in this game. Sounds bad right? Want to still buy this game? Don't, go do something better with your money because by the time you hit 30 in this game, you already can't refund the son of a ♥♥♥♥♥. Now on to the glitches. They have already announced patches for a bunch of bugs in the 1.2 update. Will it fix them? Unlikely. In the 1.1 update which you can read the patch notes somewhere online, they announced a bunch of bugs would be fixed... They didn't fix them, because the community went right back to doing the exact same ♥♥♥♥ a different way. If you don't abuse these glitches in the dz, then you're good as ♥♥♥♥ed.

I'm a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at what Massive has made this community into, but then again they don't care about what the community thinks. I bought the game for retail for $60 and played the PvE aspect of it (which the PvE is just long enough for you not to get your refund back) and i thought this game would even get better in the future. So i ♥♥♥♥ing bought the season pass. Now this game is infested with hackers and the devs don't care. They've already made their money. If you buy this game then i wish you the best of luck.

reviewText:
Product received for free

My first review was positive, about 25 hours in, and having played the beta and loving it. There were plenty of bugs to be found, but I figured release would be alright, since most everyone was having similar bugs. It wasn't, almost nothing had changed. My second review was probably a little unfair to Hamish, so I deleted that one.

So that brings us to review three. Written on the day I uninstalled the game.

Pros
-Stunning graphics.
-Cool concept.
-Gunfights are fun if you aren't trying to kill/fend off a hacker.
-I actually can't think of any more, the more I try, the more I realize I didn't like this game very much after completing the campaign the first time. Up until that point, it was fun.

Cons
-Broken. Everything is broken. You fall through the floor constantly, graphics glitch out, displayed stats are a joke, they constantly change even without equipping new gear, and have all been that way since beta.
-Broken. It's bad enough that it deserves a second one.
-Hackers. Sure they banned some, But I went into the DZ for two minutes today and saw one, so, yeah.
-The devs think that increasing difficulty means just adding more grenade spamming enemies and giving them more armor.
-Every mission is the same. Not similar, the same. There are like 3 or 4 variations, and they are all boring as hell.


This game could have been awesome, the concept and the Tom Clancy name should have delivered a much better product with more depth and nuance, but instead the devs gave us a clown car filled with bags of dogsh*t.

The story is worth a playthrough if you get it on a deep, deep sale or as a gift, but not any other time, in my opinion.


TL;DR

I tried to like it, I put my time in to make sure I wasn't just in a funk, but this game is broken on nearly every level, and the devs seem totally incapable of (or indifferent to) fixing it so far.

reviewText:
Add me to the disheartened and disappointed.

While the game was awesome up until the big patch that added the new Incursions, it appears that was because I always played with friends and we rarely had time for the ( PvP ) Dark Zone. Upon hitting level 30 ( max ), we discovered the end game content was simply repeat the exact same missions you did for the story and grind to level 30 over and over and over again.

Then we decide to go to the Dark Zone where we were not constantly encountering hackers and cheaters, but several times we were mowed down while behind cover by 1 guy who seemed to be able to shoot through the cover. New patch also introduces 'Dark Zone Supply Crate drops' and we get quite a few of them, only to find that the ♥♥♥♥♥ in them is completely useless and rarely gold. ( gold is the only thing that matters now with the crafting nerf - see other reviews that detail this hoax by Massive ).

The journey to 30 was great, and provided over 200 hours of fun, so I can not say it wasn't worth the money, but the idea that it is supossed to keep you playing is a joke. Massive needs to learn the #1 rule in a server-client relationship: Never trust the client. Ignoring this rule leads to Aimbots, shoot through walls, walk through walls, flying, whatever the client wants. Dumb asses that thought it would work LOL.

Anyway, as you can see for yourself there are a huge amount of people very disappointed at the state of the game today, and unless it changes ( I estimate a 10% chance of that ) I will not be playing.

Early game = 9/10
End game = 1/10
PvP = 0/10

Overall = 5/10

If it is your kind of game, then it should give you plenty of fun and be worth your $60 ( currently ). I do not really regret buying it. But do not expect it to hold your interest after hitting level 30.

reviewText: First problem: I bet that many of us, like me, are stuck at around 190-200 gs and haven't been able to find an upgrade to their gear in days or weeks. It's simply too hard to get upgrades at this point. The gear ceiling is too low. Reaching DZ rank 50, 75, and 90 takes a hell of a long time and even when you do reach them, the 204 blue prints you can buy will probably end up with weak rolls or if they are an upgrade, they aren't better by much. Most of us don't have the 240 gear because Falcon Lost CM is nearly impossible to do with a matchmaking group and it is the only way to obtain it. 240 gear is too hard to get for the average player.\n\n204 gear is also too hard to get for the average player. 204 items show up once a week in the BoO and in the DZ. The 204 items in the BoO statistically have a very rare chance of being useful. Once you have Sentry gear then the only pieces of 204 gear that are useful are reckless chest and savage gloves. We got lucky a couple of weeks ago and had that 204 brutal Aug. Its unlikely an upgrade to our weapons or gear will show up in the BoO. In the DZ the 204 blueprints aren't enough of an upgrade to grind for the DZ level and credit requirement. I don't think, like many others do, that the cost and level requirements are too high. It would be cool if the blueprints unlocked at lvl 75 were huge upgrades because then it would be exciting to grind towards that goal. But even god rolls on 204 items aren't much better than 182 items with a good roll.

reviewText:
Before I say anything else, let me stress here and now that I LOVE(d) this game to bits.

This game is just SO pretty!  There are so many little things like footprints in the snow where you've stepped and bullet holes on anything and everything you shoot.  It is just lovely to look at.  The mechanics of the game are very solid.  It has a great cover system, combat works rather well, and there are a fairly large number of talents and skills to choose from.  The possible weapons you can have with their talents and the bonuses that you can get from your gear.  It's like some crazy love child of Diablo and Borderlands.  10/10 It's a blast!"

All in all there is a great framework for a great game here that I would be more than happy to dump hours into without a moment of regret...

...that is when it works.

reviewText: I could not, in good conscience, recommend this game to anyone at the moment.  The end game is entirely based around a forced PvP area(to acquire crafting materials referred to as division tech) that is plagued with hackers who upon killing you can cost you up to a half hours worth of gameplay in progress(since the PvP area has penalties for death whether or not you have killed another player).\n\nThe hackers themselves are not the reason I cannot recommend this game, it is the complete lack of transparency or visible effort by Ubisoft to crack down on the hackers.  They are more concerned with punishing individuals who abuse the glitch filled PvE raid/horde mode" in a verbal and visible manner
date: than they are with fixing their forced PvP hack fest.  The evidence of this lack of effort to crack down on hackers is evidenced in the sheer prevalence of it.  If hacking was being properly tracked and punished
recommended: hackers would not be so prominent or easily identifiable in the manner that they currently are.\n\nThere are hackers that literally stream and post on youtube that are still playing the game even though they are open and provide evidence themselves that they are hacking.  There is no fair play system that provides after startup checking of game files
hoursPlayed: and while this measure is not a fool-proof prevention method

reviewText: Let me summarize the normal routine for most people playing the Division in the last month and a half: exploit farm, developer patch, return to dark zone to gank the undergeared, find new exploit, rinse and repeat. The hacking and exploiting is so rampant that if you are not doing one or the other then you are being left behind. The developers say the dark zone offers the best loot, well in my experience the dark zone loot is on par with the stuff you find on the outside. The only incentive to go into the dark zone is to grind dark zone levels to buy blueprints because the random loot that drops from mobs and bosses within the dark zone are all worthless crap. Also, the developers like to quickly patch things that people enjoy (such as receiving 4 High End gear from Challenge mode boss) while taking their time to fix major exploits and hacking.

reviewText:
GRFS wasn't as hard to love as this.

Considering how much better netcode is for the Division, I found this thought incredibly hillarious. We used to make offerings to the God of P2P connectivity just to find a good match.

As it is an RPG, the grind combined with the pitfalls of pvp make competitive spirit absolutely necessary in the Dark Zone. As the Dark Zone is intended to be the primary end-game experience for all users, buy this title with an understanding that you'll need to strive to be stronger in order to be comfortable with playing.

This is a title where the strong eat the weak, if you and your friends aren't prepared to do what's necessary to become stronger, you'll only make things harder on yourselves. Forget what the official reviewers are saying, the playerbase is only marginally trustworthy until you reach the endgame. Because the penalty of death is forfeiture of experience and funds, your progress will be stymied if you invest too much trust in non-hostile players. All it takes is for you to present an opportunity and you will instantly be shot in the back.

Trust none but your friends. At least friendly fire is turned off.

reviewerDisplayName: Prof. Dr. Sir Lord Master, Esq.
reviewText:
BOTTOM LINE UP FRONT: When my estimation of what this game is worth meets or exceeds the asking price, I'll change this review to recommended.
My Est: (Core Game + DLC) [$40 + $20] versus asking of: [$60 + $40]

I still like this game and it has a lot of potential to become something amazing.  I'm eager to see what the DLC will bring.

THE GOOD: It's a fresh take on MMO-ish FPS mechanics and gameplay with lots of attention to detail in the general environments.  With an interesting Tom Clancy-esque storyline as a backdrop, the game has great potential to become more interesting / enjoyable.

THE BAD: The new Incursion isn't very much fun to play, if it is an indicator of what the game will have in store for us later, then I'm dreading the expansion content.

Additionally the game has been historically muddled with cheaters and exploiters making the DZ an unfair and precarious place while additionally causing server instability.  (but recent mass suspensions and bans have helped address this problem with great success)

THE UGLY: The general chats are still cluttered with auto chat spamming bots advertising assisted leveling posted by names that no one can ignore or report that auto re-spam whenever anyone else types in chat.

FOR WHAT IT'S WORTH: I'd say it's worth between 30 - 60 bucks for the core game + DLCs, but until these issues are cleared up it's hard to say its worth any more than 20-40 bucks just for the single player / PvE experience.

Maybe after all the DLC is out and the game can police itself, it might be worth its initial asking price of 100 bucks again... (core game + season's pass / Gold Edition cost)  we'll just have to wait and see...


Update May 6th 2016:

The DZ seems to be clear of hackers and Griefers, good on Massive.

But on the bad side there are still auto chat spammer bots trying to sell lvling services in the Pennsylvania Avenue District and Stuyvesant, (the Falcon Lost Area)  which really annoys me.  This should really be ultra simple to fix guys, like easier than ridding DZ of cheaters...  Why are we still bombarded with spam in general chats???


Update April 29th 2016:

Ok, so today I barely worked up enough motivation to play, so I started on a Daily Mission, in this case Grand Central Station, and about 1-2 minutes from completing the mission the server dumps me...  I continually try to connect over the next 4-5 minutes but the server just keeps dumping me after it loads, which people can tell you can take a couple to several minutes sometimes...  only to find myself outside the mission area, my team completed it without me...

Which means I would have to do the mission all over again...   So I switch the game off, frustrated I did something else ... (anything else) for a few hours, then being the masochist I am I load it up again and go to complete the same daily, since my character was conveniently saved right outside the mission area I hold G to set the difficulty and redo it...  then the server punts me again...

Fine Ubisoft AND Massive... I won't play your broken game, le sigh...  I still wanna play it though...



Posted circa April 23rd, 2016

The end-game mechanic Dark Zone is filled to the gills with glitchers, cheaters, and script kiddies, doing anything from shooting you through half a block of buildings with precise accuracy, one shotting you, flying in the air, to running around with the speed of the flash.

Not to mention that if you are an honest player who doesn't strive for scripts or ill-gotten gains, then you'd best prepare yourself to lose anything you might gain stepping into the Dark Zone.

And what is the game without the Dark Zone?  well, some fairly decent shooter experience until you complete the story, which should only take the casual player maybe a week or two at most to complete, then all you have left to you are the dailies which seem to be identical every day.  (is it assigning due to the zone you are in when they pop?  Has ubisoft realized almost everyone goes back to penns [base of operations] at the end of the day?)

The server seems to be regularly punting groups of players, as when I go to load back in I suddenly find myself in a que between 100 - 400+ long waiting to get in, are the exploits crashign the server now???

As a regular player of the division, I'm feeling abandoned by the devs, could it really be so hard to put 1 dev or chatbot into the server to clean up the spam?  Would it really be so hard to implement code that would block a player after posting THE EXACT SAME THING hundreds of times a minute???

And on a similar subject would it really be hard to put a dev or a bot into the Dark Zone that could log and identify suspicious killings?  I mean most of the cheaters go rogue as a matter of course, would it be so hard to monitor the dps / headshot accuracy of a rogue that is plowing through other players and then scan their gear to see if what they are doing makes any sense according to how the game should be functioning?   Or tracking how quickly a player is covering ground / running / flying???

The Dark Zone is a good end game mechanic for players to parkour through after they've tied up the story, but if you allow people to destroy the experience at the expense of your fair and casual gamers you've allowed the cheaters to negatively impact the game overall, forever tainting it for the majority of players, and even forcing some of them to cheat themselves just to attempt and keep up.

All in all the game is currently not worth the asking price until these problems are addressed, and certainly not worth the total $100 price tag if despite content additions the cheating and spamming are perpetually ruining the game for people.

The devs should come up with more clever AI enemies going forward (instead of just making them all more bullet spongy) as well as maybe offering characters some kind of bonus for focusing on a certain skill branch, maybe char classes?

The Dark Zone should have more PvE optional content, why isn't there anything to investigate in there?  Why couldn't there be public quest-ish areas?  offering rewards if all agents in an area work towards some kind of greater goal, (like retaking the pit) and give agents the option of turning Friendly fire on / off in the quest, and making those with FF off still able to shoot rogues in the quest area etc...

And maybe even do something similar for Rogues, like a few neutral areas in the DZ that can be controlled ultimately by Aaron Keener and player rogues vs Faye Lau and non rogue agents fighting over a multi part area, giving DZ $ rewards and gear for retaking an area.  (just make it so it can only occur every 2 hrs after the area has been taken etc.)

Additionally Incursions should be more immersive instead of forcing a near impossible multi wave defense scenario, maybe where there are NPCs involved and if you can protect them while they do something the mission is easier, and make it so it only defaults to something like Falcon Lost, if the players aren't doing what they should...  otherwise it's all just a tedious slog...

reviewText: First problem: I bet that many of us, like me, are stuck at around 190-200 gs and haven't been able to find an upgrade to their gear in days or weeks. It's simply too hard to get upgrades at this point. The gear ceiling is too low. Reaching DZ rank 50, 75, and 90 takes a hell of a long time and even when you do reach them, the 204 blue prints you can buy will probably end up with weak rolls or if they are an upgrade, they aren't better by much. Most of us don't have the 240 gear because Falcon Lost CM is nearly impossible to do with a matchmaking group and it is the only way to obtain it. 240 gear is too hard to get for the average player.\n\n204 gear is also too hard to get for the average player. 204 items show up once a week in the BoO and in the DZ. The 204 items in the BoO statistically have a very rare chance of being useful. Once you have Sentry gear then the only pieces of 204 gear that are useful are reckless chest and savage gloves. We got lucky a couple of weeks ago and had that 204 brutal Aug. Its unlikely an upgrade to our weapons or gear will show up in the BoO. In the DZ the 204 blueprints aren't enough of an upgrade to grind for the DZ level and credit requirement. I don't think, like many others do, that the cost and level requirements are too high. It would be cool if the blueprints unlocked at lvl 75 were huge upgrades because then it would be exciting to grind towards that goal. But even god rolls on 204 items aren't much better than 182 items with a good roll.

reviewText:
Product received for free

My first review was positive, about 25 hours in, and having played the beta and loving it. There were plenty of bugs to be found, but I figured release would be alright, since most everyone was having similar bugs. It wasn't, almost nothing had changed. My second review was probably a little unfair to Hamish, so I deleted that one.

So that brings us to review three. Written on the day I uninstalled the game.

Pros
-Stunning graphics.
-Cool concept.
-Gunfights are fun if you aren't trying to kill/fend off a hacker.
-I actually can't think of any more, the more I try, the more I realize I didn't like this game very much after completing the campaign the first time. Up until that point, it was fun.

Cons
-Broken. Everything is broken. You fall through the floor constantly, graphics glitch out, displayed stats are a joke, they constantly change even without equipping new gear, and have all been that way since beta.
-Broken. It's bad enough that it deserves a second one.
-Hackers. Sure they banned some, But I went into the DZ for two minutes today and saw one, so, yeah.
-The devs think that increasing difficulty means just adding more grenade spamming enemies and giving them more armor.
-Every mission is the same. Not similar, the same. There are like 3 or 4 variations, and they are all boring as hell.


This game could have been awesome, the concept and the Tom Clancy name should have delivered a much better product with more depth and nuance, but instead the devs gave us a clown car filled with bags of dogsh*t.

The story is worth a playthrough if you get it on a deep, deep sale or as a gift, but not any other time, in my opinion.


TL;DR

I tried to like it, I put my time in to make sure I wasn't just in a funk, but this game is broken on nearly every level, and the devs seem totally incapable of (or indifferent to) fixing it so far.
