reviewText:
There arn't enough words to describe how badly this game is put together. I've put roughly 300-400 hours on this game and I've tried to look for every positive. Unfortunately there arn't many. So let's get the positives out of the way first so i can get to the point of this review.
-Nice graphics
That's it and that is all it ever will be, just nice graphics. Being a level 30 PvE and a Dark Zone rank of 90 i found this game to be grindy. So then i tried the PvP aspect of it and nothing but hackers and exploiters. I've seen it all now guys, the flying to the teleporting right on top of you just to kill you and teleport away. The best part is, these guys can kill you (not down you) IN ONE SHOT and what's funny about this is that they only get a slap on the rist for hacking Massive's game and killing you, taking your xp and loot. Before getting this game, look up youtube videos on the division hacks. Now, just imagine these guys in every server taking your ♥♥♥♥ everytime they just simply look at you. They have a multistep process for reporting guys like these (all of this has to be done in order for them to get banned)
1. Record 3 instances of them hacking
2. Type /report *Hacker's Name* in chat (you won't get to see their name half of the time)
3. Post it to one of their forums (either reddit, facebook, or other means)
Now after you have completed all of this you may go continue back to the game and get ♥♥♥♥♥ slapped by the same hacker until the next game-update (its when they ban people).

So that was only the tiny segment of what hacking is currently in this game. Sounds bad right? Want to still buy this game? Don't, go do something better with your money because by the time you hit 30 in this game, you already can't refund the son of a ♥♥♥♥♥. Now on to the glitches. They have already announced patches for a bunch of bugs in the 1.2 update. Will it fix them? Unlikely. In the 1.1 update which you can read the patch notes somewhere online, they announced a bunch of bugs would be fixed... They didn't fix them, because the community went right back to doing the exact same ♥♥♥♥ a different way. If you don't abuse these glitches in the dz, then you're good as ♥♥♥♥ed.

I'm a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at what Massive has made this community into, but then again they don't care about what the community thinks. I bought the game for retail for $60 and played the PvE aspect of it (which the PvE is just long enough for you not to get your refund back) and i thought this game would even get better in the future. So i ♥♥♥♥ing bought the season pass. Now this game is infested with hackers and the devs don't care. They've already made their money. If you buy this game then i wish you the best of luck.

This game is just SO pretty!  There are so many little things like footprints in the snow where you've stepped and bullet holes on anything and everything you shoot.  It is just lovely to look at. reviewText:
Add me to the disheartened and disappointed.

While the game was awesome up until the big patch that added the new Incursions, it appears that was because I always played with friends and we rarely had time for the ( PvP ) Dark Zone. Upon hitting level 30 ( max ), we discovered the end game content was simply repeat the exact same missions you did for the story and grind to level 30 over and over and over again.

Then we decide to go to the Dark Zone where we were not constantly encountering hackers and cheaters, but several times we were mowed down while behind cover by 1 guy who seemed to be able to shoot through the cover. New patch also introduces 'Dark Zone Supply Crate drops' and we get quite a few of them, only to find that the ♥♥♥♥♥ in them is completely useless and rarely gold. ( gold is the only thing that matters now with the crafting nerf - see other reviews that detail this hoax by Massive ).

The journey to 30 was great, and provided over 200 hours of fun, so I can not say it wasn't worth the money, but the idea that it is supossed to keep you playing is a joke. Massive needs to learn the #1 rule in a server-client relationship: Never trust the client. Ignoring this rule leads to Aimbots, shoot through walls, walk through walls, flying, whatever the client wants. Dumb asses that thought it would work LOL.

Anyway, as you can see for yourself there are a huge amount of people very disappointed at the state of the game today, and unless it changes ( I estimate a 10% chance of that ) I will not be playing.

Early game = 9/10
End game = 1/10
PvP = 0/10

Overall = 5/10

If it is your kind of game, then it should give you plenty of fun and be worth your $60 ( currently ). I do not really regret buying it. But do not expect it to hold your interest after hitting level 30.

reviewText:
The Division is another example of why Ubisoft published titles should be avoided in the early stages, or even considered at all.

Great ideas blurred with broken mechanics, hacking in key areas of the game with no server to client control due to poor online infostructure, matchmaking issues, overall content is shallow and blindingly repetitive, the game engine is anything but impressive at times, and the  player to player interaction reminds me of how integrated voice support can work against the health of the game.

I was conviced that this was another Watch Dogs, Unity, or FarCry Primal, and boy did Ubisoft prove me right.

For every aspect you enjoy in The Division, there will be a 5:1 ratio of poor experiences, that will dissipate any incentive you are feeling about progression, or commitment to your character(s).

Shame on you again Ubisoft. You are the bane of the industry, and you are responsible for developer misdirection and control, that helped lead The Division to one of the most disapointing titles of 2016 in less than two months time.

reviewText: Let me summarize the normal routine for most people playing the Division in the last month and a half: exploit farm, developer patch, return to dark zone to gank the undergeared, find new exploit, rinse and repeat. The hacking and exploiting is so rampant that if you are not doing one or the other then you are being left behind. The developers say the dark zone offers the best loot, well in my experience the dark zone loot is on par with the stuff you find on the outside. The only incentive to go into the dark zone is to grind dark zone levels to buy blueprints because the random loot that drops from mobs and bosses within the dark zone are all worthless crap. Also, the developers like to quickly patch things that people enjoy (such as receiving 4 High End gear from Challenge mode boss) while taking their time to fix major exploits and hacking.

reviewText:
GRFS wasn't as hard to love as this.

Considering how much better netcode is for the Division, I found this thought incredibly hillarious. We used to make offerings to the God of P2P connectivity just to find a good match.

As it is an RPG, the grind combined with the pitfalls of pvp make competitive spirit absolutely necessary in the Dark Zone. As the Dark Zone is intended to be the primary end-game experience for all users, buy this title with an understanding that you'll need to strive to be stronger in order to be comfortable with playing.

This is a title where the strong eat the weak, if you and your friends aren't prepared to do what's necessary to become stronger, you'll only make things harder on yourselves. Forget what the official reviewers are saying, the playerbase is only marginally trustworthy until you reach the endgame. Because the penalty of death is forfeiture of experience and funds, your progress will be stymied if you invest too much trust in non-hostile players. All it takes is for you to present an opportunity and you will instantly be shot in the back.

Trust none but your friends. At least friendly fire is turned off.

reviewerDisplayName: Prof. Dr. Sir Lord Master, Esq.
reviewText:
BOTTOM LINE UP FRONT: When my estimation of what this game is worth meets or exceeds the asking price, I'll change this review to recommended.
My Est: (Core Game + DLC) [$40 + $20] versus asking of: [$60 + $40]

I still like this game and it has a lot of potential to become something amazing.  I'm eager to see what the DLC will bring.

THE GOOD: It's a fresh take on MMO-ish FPS mechanics and gameplay with lots of attention to detail in the general environments.  With an interesting Tom Clancy-esque storyline as a backdrop, the game has great potential to become more interesting / enjoyable.

THE BAD: The new Incursion isn't very much fun to play, if it is an indicator of what the game will have in store for us later, then I'm dreading the expansion content.

Additionally the game has been historically muddled with cheaters and exploiters making the DZ an unfair and precarious place while additionally causing server instability.  (but recent mass suspensions and bans have helped address this problem with great success)

THE UGLY: The general chats are still cluttered with auto chat spamming bots advertising assisted leveling posted by names that no one can ignore or report that auto re-spam whenever anyone else types in chat.

FOR WHAT IT'S WORTH: I'd say it's worth between 30 - 60 bucks for the core game + DLCs, but until these issues are cleared up it's hard to say its worth any more than 20-40 bucks just for the single player / PvE experience.

Maybe after all the DLC is out and the game can police itself, it might be worth its initial asking price of 100 bucks again... (core game + season's pass / Gold Edition cost)  we'll just have to wait and see...


Update May 6th 2016:

The DZ seems to be clear of hackers and Griefers, good on Massive.

But on the bad side there are still auto chat spammer bots trying to sell lvling services in the Pennsylvania Avenue District and Stuyvesant, (the Falcon Lost Area)  which really annoys me.  This should really be ultra simple to fix guys, like easier than ridding DZ of cheaters...  Why are we still bombarded with spam in general chats???


Update April 29th 2016:

Ok, so today I barely worked up enough motivation to play, so I started on a Daily Mission, in this case Grand Central Station, and about 1-2 minutes from completing the mission the server dumps me...  I continually try to connect over the next 4-5 minutes but the server just keeps dumping me after it loads, which people can tell you can take a couple to several minutes sometimes...  only to find myself outside the mission area, my team completed it without me...

Which means I would have to do the mission all over again...   So I switch the game off, frustrated I did something else ... (anything else) for a few hours, then being the masochist I am I load it up again and go to complete the same daily, since my character was conveniently saved right outside the mission area I hold G to set the difficulty and redo it...  then the server punts me again...

Fine Ubisoft AND Massive... I won't play your broken game, le sigh...  I still wanna play it though...



Posted circa April 23rd, 2016

The end-game mechanic Dark Zone is filled to the gills with glitchers, cheaters, and script kiddies, doing anything from shooting you through half a block of buildings with precise accuracy, one shotting you, flying in the air, to running around with the speed of the flash.

Not to mention that if you are an honest player who doesn't strive for scripts or ill-gotten gains, then you'd best prepare yourself to lose anything you might gain stepping into the Dark Zone.

And what is the game without the Dark Zone?  well, some fairly decent shooter experience until you complete the story, which should only take the casual player maybe a week or two at most to complete, then all you have left to you are the dailies which seem to be identical every day.  (is it assigning due to the zone you are in when they pop?  Has ubisoft realized almost everyone goes back to penns [base of operations] at the end of the day?)

The server seems to be regularly punting groups of players, as when I go to load back in I suddenly find myself in a que between 100 - 400+ long waiting to get in, are the exploits crashign the server now???

As a regular player of the division, I'm feeling abandoned by the devs, could it really be so hard to put 1 dev or chatbot into the server to clean up the spam?  Would it really be so hard to implement code that would block a player after posting THE EXACT SAME THING hundreds of times a minute???

And on a similar subject would it really be hard to put a dev or a bot into the Dark Zone that could log and identify suspicious killings?  I mean most of the cheaters go rogue as a matter of course, would it be so hard to monitor the dps / headshot accuracy of a rogue that is plowing through other players and then scan their gear to see if what they are doing makes any sense according to how the game should be functioning?   Or tracking how quickly a player is covering ground / running / flying???

The Dark Zone is a good end game mechanic for players to parkour through after they've tied up the story, but if you allow people to destroy the experience at the expense of your fair and casual gamers you've allowed the cheaters to negatively impact the game overall, forever tainting it for the majority of players, and even forcing some of them to cheat themselves just to attempt and keep up.

All in all the game is currently not worth the asking price until these problems are addressed, and certainly not worth the total $100 price tag if despite content additions the cheating and spamming are perpetually ruining the game for people.

The devs should come up with more clever AI enemies going forward (instead of just making them all more bullet spongy) as well as maybe offering characters some kind of bonus for focusing on a certain skill branch, maybe char classes?

The Dark Zone should have more PvE optional content, why isn't there anything to investigate in there?  Why couldn't there be public quest-ish areas?  offering rewards if all agents in an area work towards some kind of greater goal, (like retaking the pit) and give agents the option of turning Friendly fire on / off in the quest, and making those with FF off still able to shoot rogues in the quest area etc...

And maybe even do something similar for Rogues, like a few neutral areas in the DZ that can be controlled ultimately by Aaron Keener and player rogues vs Faye Lau and non rogue agents fighting over a multi part area, giving DZ $ rewards and gear for retaking an area.  (just make it so it can only occur every 2 hrs after the area has been taken etc.)

Additionally Incursions should be more immersive instead of forcing a near impossible multi wave defense scenario, maybe where there are NPCs involved and if you can protect them while they do something the mission is easier, and make it so it only defaults to something like Falcon Lost, if the players aren't doing what they should...  otherwise it's all just a tedious slog...

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game... I really did.

Unfortunately, I have to give it a negative review. I'll save you a lot of reading and say 3.5/10. Do not buy.

This game is visually beautiful, but that is about the only redeeming quality of it at this point, as it is a buggy, repetitive, duck and cover style shooter. Not quite as open world as they would have you believe. The story missions are pretty much the same as you progress through the game. Recovering stolen shipments, killing mindless AI, and the occasional instance (that you inevitably repeat at max level ad naseum).

This game is poorly managed, as every step of the way there is some game breaking bug that people are taking advantage of... early on, it was bullet king (which took them over a week to fix...) granting players pretty much infinite phoenix credits assuming they were able to put up with repetitive grinding of the same world boss" for long enough.

There is also Dark zone XP farming exploits where you can go off the map and basically kill your friends for ridiculous XP gains

reviewText:
I have never written a review but felt the need to do that for this game.  I will not waste your time talking about my skills or anything like that...im just a person who plays a LOT of games and really waited to play this one ever since I saw it at E3.  This and Fallout 4 were the games I was dying to play.  Opening day had some trouble but soon I was playing with friends and leveling up.  We were having a great time...shooting dogs and going through missions.  Then the darkzone trips.  I found that most people in DZ01 - DZ03 were like me.....just wanting to grab gear and get out.  We were always in the DZ with the same approximate level people so if we did accidently go rogue we had a good fighting chance.
Then we beat the game and reached level 30.  The game seriously went downhill from there.  The PC version of this game is riddled with hackers and glitchers.  After trying a few darkzone runs and having moderate success I found roving gangs of poachers that were killing people for nothing.  I found the loot chests always empty because apparently they are constantly checked by everyone and its pure luck to find one with any gold tech in it.  The crafting system update is a total joke...its astounding how hard it is to craft now.
The solo or PVE coop is great from levels 1-30 and the basic game is good.  The enemies are mindless but thats ok in the scheme of things.  My main problems deal with the serious lack of quality control on the release of this game, and the hackers arent making things any better.  Its becoming a hack and have a fighting chance" type of game and for people that honestly do not hack or glitch and play the game as it was installed this is not a fun game after level 30.  I get that they have daily's for some kind of replayability...I get that they have these incursions for some other content but they should just skip that and fix this game.
To end a long rant for what I paid for the basic game I think I got what I paid for.  I got a 0-30 game to play PVE coop story/campaign with friends.  It should have just ended there."

reviewText:
The Division is another example of why Ubisoft published titles should be avoided in the early stages, or even considered at all.

Great ideas blurred with broken mechanics, hacking in key areas of the game with no server to client control due to poor online infostructure, matchmaking issues, overall content is shallow and blindingly repetitive, the game engine is anything but impressive at times, and the  player to player interaction reminds me of how integrated voice support can work against the health of the game.

I was conviced that this was another Watch Dogs, Unity, or FarCry Primal, and boy did Ubisoft prove me right.

For every aspect you enjoy in The Division, there will be a 5:1 ratio of poor experiences, that will dissipate any incentive you are feeling about progression, or commitment to your character(s).

Shame on you again Ubisoft. You are the bane of the industry, and you are responsible for developer misdirection and control, that helped lead The Division to one of the most disapointing titles of 2016 in less than two months time.

reviewText:
Lots of potential but disappointing execution.

Pros:
* Fun to explore the city though you are limited to a small portion of NYC and can only safely explore a few zones without grinding levels.
* The PvP Dark Zone is a cool concept but has balance issues.
* Good cover system.

Cons:
* Takes literally hundreds of bullets to take down someone who is a few levels above your level.
* Did I mention everything takes tons of bullets to kill?
* Favors grinding over skill.
* Most crafting supplies are useless as enemies drop perfectly capable weapons for completing the main missions. It's not until end game when crafting even begins to make sense.
* Missions are very linear and boring: go here, clear the area, repeat.
* Spending time to finding/crafting good weapons/armor for your level is wasteful. Simply progress through the story and gaining levels will make you immensly more powerful.
* Skills and abilities are underwhelming and aside from one healing ability don't contribute anything significant to combat.

reviewText:
This is a great game if you like getting killed repeatedly and not having a prayer of killing back.  The glitchers got so far ahead on gear due to the buggy as  heck release that the only hope is for a raised level cap and new high end gear releases.  I saw a group of 8 running together.  One was a rogue to draw people in, the rest were the trap.  Since the game limits groups to 4, unless you know a bunch of gamers, you can't compete.

Summary:  unbalanced, unbalanced and unbalanced, do not recommend anyone pick it up at this point.  If they fix it, the core game is awesome fun.

To echo a request added by so many others, put in a passive dark zone and let the kids kill each other in the hostile dark zone.

reviewText:
Oh boy, where do I begin...

I had a lot of hope for this game. The trailers and gameplay videos showed a lot of promise. After playing for a solid month, I have to say that Ubisoft are masters of selling an un-finished product.

Massive need to get their act together, listen to their playerbase, and correct the multitude of bugs plaguing this product. The toxicity of the Dark Zone is enough for the majority of players to just stay away, but there's not enough content anywhere else in the game, despite promises of future DLCs.

I would only recommend this game to players intent on going Rogue the entire time they're logged in.

I would suggest not buying it until the hacking problem which is f'ing out of control is dealt with. The icing on the cake regarding this situation is hackers only get 3 day bans and not perma-bans. Ubisoft + Massive = garb confirmed.\n\nUpdate 5/18/2016: They ended up taking some action against hackers and all was well for about a week. The dream was short lived and they are back in full force with even greater numbers. Oh and also they plan on implementing the ability to cut the extraction rope. I'm already having nightmares of hackers teleporting around cutting ropes.

reviewText:
Complete and utter crap!

Games are something that should be fun to play, I mean they are a big time waster so shouldn't the games we play be fun & feel rewarding.
The Division is a good concept that has a very poor delivery, I play games to pass time and have fun, The Division is a game that has a few missions to get an FOB setup & has just grind after, To me a game with just grind is not fun, I am not a baby that needs to collect all the pretty colored gear to feel special that SH*T is not fun at all.
I find the game falls flat after the FOB is at 100% there is no reason a game that costs $60 should make someone feel bored & think should I play something else to pass time.

Hands down I do not feel I could recommend this game to anyone.
Complete crap!

reviewText:
Beta highlighted some issues, were they adressed sort of.
Games was released and there were issues, were they addressed, sort of.
DLC came out and there were issues, were they addressed, sort of.
This is a game that feels like it is being developed by a divided commitee.
PVP How is this justified by the story? Agents shooting each other after saving part of the city? The story line had so much potential, but in the end it is something that gets scratched as an outline and nothing further done with it. This should never have had a Tom Clancy moniker and I think for a man who strived for realism, this would not have left a good taste.

reviewText:
I've more then gotten my money's worth out of the game. Unfortunately, the developer & publisher failed to forsee the security flaws, which allow hackers and exploiters to thrive in the darkzone (PVPE).

**Hackers begin to be banned, but damage to the  player base numbers is significant.

At first there were few hackers and the exploiters couldn't out gear folks to bad, but with the expansion a gear gap is significant and hackers have become numerous. Additionally, the developer thinks AoE spam increases the challenge of the incursion level, which takes place in one large room with mind numbing waves of NPCs. Also, the developer continues to set crafting and material ratios based on exploiters, which kills these actions for average players. It's nearly impossible to perfect a character build due to the RNG (random number generator) loot system, which only allows you to adjust one stat category.

The first month will probably be the best the time the player base has had with the game due to the minimal population of hackers. This game has stunning eye candy and solid third person shooter mechanics, but it falls flat in security and therefore is untrustworthy of steady entertainment as it developes.

Buyer beware!

Edit: 29May2016

Game updated to 1.2 this week and the patch broke as much as it fixed. There's a new 201+ Gear Score DZ, which is set primarily to teams of four players and isn't worth solo players time as they're just a DZ ATM for teams to rogue unless a titan build or have above average reflexes due to the higher level NPC.

When teamed with seasoned players, I've observed Meta-teams of 6-8 rogues work a server over with player limit of 24 without serious challenge. The game's playerbase is condensed to the overgeared and/or the highly skilled and those players to stubborn or to clueless to quit in the GS201+ DZ.

Might makes Right in the DZ per the design. Unfortunately, the Metagame usurps any end game intentions the developers have for the DZ.

On PVE side the once a week HVT (High Value Target) rewards stagnates interest and character developement.

reviewText:
In what had to be one of the most anticipated games of the year turned into a major disaster. There are just too many cons to make this game worth buying full price, given its current state. More and more publishers are turning to these types of tactics of anticipation, and promise, only to deliver an un-finished, giant piece of s***.


-- Cons
----------------

- Bugs/Glitches
-----------------
Ubisoft can't even release a legitimate  patch to fix all the crap that is wrong with this game. From the release this game was broke as all f*** but waited over a month to release a patch that still broke the game. Fix your damn teleportation of enemies as well. And I have never in my life seen a game where an enemy can run to cover, and then instantly be on target and some how teleport to a vehicle. I laugh every time.

- Weapons/Gear Sets/Loot
-----------------------------
While there is copius amounts of loot to pick up, it's the same ♥♥♥♥ over and over with marginal to no gains no matter how much you grind. I have grinded over 200 hours into this game and still have yet to see what exactly is the best gear/and or weapons. Weapon balance is a joke. Ubisoft's ability to try to introduce real world weapons into the game turned into a joke. A real world KRISS Vector .45 SMG sprays out over 1200 rounds a second, but the top in the game is 900? Get your s*** straight with real world weapons before you put them in a game.

Gear Sets were introduced and completely ruined the game. Half of them are pointless and are worse than high-end items. I highly doubt this will ever be fixed because lets be honest, Ubisoft doesn't care.


- Dark Zone
--------------------
You had one job and you half-♥♥♥♥♥ it. Oh way to introduce a server-side anti-cheat system, LAWLZ. Hackers pretty much run rampent in the dark zone, so I suggest just staying out of there, otherwise you will want to break everything you own. The risk of going to get loot out of the dark zone has been marginal and honestly not worth dying a million times for.

- Incursions
-----------------

I get the idea behind incursions, but you have literally made it impossible to complete on ones own. If I want to complete the incursions on my own, I shouldn't need a tank to win. You could have the best gear in the game and still get destroyed. And lets be honest, one incursion a month? Did you cut your team down to 5 people and said go create this retardness?

- Season Pass
-----------------
Giant waste of money. Wait till everything is out, because for $40 US, I have yet to see anything worth the money or wait.

- End-Game
---------------
That end-game will be the worst ever created in the history of gaming if Ubisoft fails to add more to the story or to the single player campaign.


++ Positives
----------------

Oh s*** there are positives to this game? Yes, but very few.

The game had a lot of potential and has a decent story. While the there are plenty of single players missions to accomplish along with side missions made it enjoyable to play for a little bit but that is about it.

Thanks for the profits when I cashed in my stock on your company Ubisoft, as that's about the only thing profitible out of this entire mess. In all honesty, I would wait on this game until it's on sale or if you just want a time waster. Ubisoft should be more like CD Red Projekt instead. At least they have a willingness to make their games right and know when s*** is broke.

I honestly hope Escape from Tarkov destroys this game. Even DayZ is better than this POS and that game is still broke ASF.
